abstract: Background: This study evaluated the immunogenicity and safety of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine using tetanus (T) toxoid as carrier protein (MenACWY-TT) co-administered with combined diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) versus their separate administration in adolescents and young adults. Methods: In this phase III, randomized, partially-blind study (NCT01767376), healthy 11–25-year-olds (N = 660) were randomized (1:1:1) to receive MenACWY-TT and Tdap at Month 0 (Co-ad group), MenACWY-TT at Month 0 and Tdap at Month 1 (ACWY_Tdap group) or Tdap at Month 0 and MenACWY-TT at Month 1 (Tdap_ACWY group). Immune responses to MenACWY-TT were measured by serum bactericidal assay using rabbit complement (rSBA). Anti-diphtheria (D), anti-tetanus (T), anti-pertussis toxin (PT), anti-filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) and anti-pertactin (PRN) antibody concentrations were assessed using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays. Non-inferiority of immunogenicity was assessed using pre-defined clinical criteria. Safety was also evaluated. Results: Non-inferiority of immunogenicity of MenACWY-TT and Tdap when co-administered versus their separate administration was demonstrated in terms of rSBA geometric mean titers (GMTs) for 4 meningococcal serogroups and of the percentage of participants with antibody concentrations >1 IU/ml for D and T. Among the pertussis antigens, non-inferiority criteria for geometric mean concentrations (GMCs) were reached for PT, but not met for FHA and PRN. Across all groups, ≥93.2% of participants had vaccine responses to each meningococcal serogroup, ≥99.1% were seroprotected against T and D, and ≥85.5% had booster responses to each pertussis antigen. Robust increases in antibody GMTs/GMCs were observed for all antigens between pre-and post-vaccination. Both vaccines had clinically acceptable safety profiles. Conclusion: Immune responses to MenACWY-TT and to the T and D antigens from Tdap were not impacted by their co-administration. The lower antibody concentrations observed against the pertussis components may be of limited clinical relevance since robust anti-pertussis booster responses were observed. This study supports concurrent administration of the 2 vaccines in adolescents.

author_highlights.sentence: We evaluated the co-administration of MenACWY-TT and Tdap in 11–25-year-olds.
Co-administration did not impact immune response to MenACWY-TT, diphtheria, tetanus.
Anti-pertussis antibody concentrations seemed lower following co-administration.
Robust post-Tdap anti-pertussis booster responses were observed in all groups.
Both vaccines had a clinically acceptable safety profile in both groups.

body_text.sentence: For all groups, antibody GMCs increased ≥9.1-fold for PT, ≥11.1-fold for FHA and ≥19.3-fold for PRN from pre-vaccination to 1 month post-Tdap administration, with the highest GMC value and fold increase in the Tdap_ACWY group for all 3 pertussis components (Table 1).

body_text.sentence: Of 692 enrolled participants (232 in Co-ad, 228 in ACWY_Tdap and 232 in Tdap_ACWY groups), 684 completed the study, 691 were included in the TVC and 671 in the ATP immunogenicity cohort (Fig. 1).

body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Three quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccines are currently available [8]: MenACWY-TT (Nimenrix, Pfizer) using tetanus (T) toxoid as carrier protein, which is indicated for individuals from the age of 6 weeks in Europe [9,10]; MenACWY-DT (Menactra, Sanofi Pasteur Inc.) with diphtheria (D) toxoid as carrier protein [11], for individuals aged 9 months to 55 years in the United States (US) [12]; and MenACWY-CRM197 (Menveo, GSK), using diphtheria CRM197 protein as carrier protein, for individuals from the age of 2 years in Europe [13], Canada and Australia [14], and for infants from 2 months up to 55 years in the US [15,16].

body_text.sentence: Secondary objectives evaluated the percentages of participants with rSBA titers ≥1:8 and ≥1:128 and vaccine responses for each meningococcal serogroup, anti-D and anti-T antibody GMCs, and booster responses to PT, FHA and PRN; compared the immunogenicity of MenACWY-TT when given before and after Tdap, and of Tdap when given before and after MenACWY-TT; and assessed the reactogenicity and safety of the study vaccines.
body_text.title: Objectives

body_text.sentence: Similar to our findings, in other studies that assessed the impact of concurrent vaccination of Tdap with other vaccines on its immunogenicity (e.g. MenACWY-DT; Fluarix, GSK), non-inferiority criteria were not met for PRN and/or FHA GMCs.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Anti-D and anti-T antibodies were measured by an in-house enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA), with concentrations of 0.1 International Units/mL (IU/mL) considered as seroprotective (assays cut-offs: 0.057 IU/mL for anti-D and 0.043 IU/mL for anti-T) [30].
body_text.title: Immunogenicity assessment

body_text.sentence: The co-primary objectives were assessed in a hierarchical manner to demonstrate: (1) the non-inferiority of MenACWY-TT co-administered with Tdap compared to MenACWY-TT given alone in terms of geometric mean titers (GMTs) against MenA, MenC, MenW and MenY as assessed by serum bactericidal assay using baby rabbit complement (rSBA); the non-inferiority of Tdap co-administered with MenACWY-TT compared to Tdap given alone in terms of (2) the percentage of participants with post-vaccination concentration >1 IU/ml for D and T and (3) geometric mean concentrations (GMCs) for PT, FHA and PRN.
body_text.title: Objectives

body_text.sentence: This type of interference was previously described as reduced immune responses due to interactions between a conjugate protein and unrelated antigens which are simultaneously or sequentially administered, and a possible mechanism is competition for the use of lymph node resources [42,43].
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Although for PT and PRN, GMCs in the Tdap_ACWY group were higher than in the Co-ad group, we observed at least a 9-fold increase in the GMCs for all 3 components in the Co-ad group.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Non-inferiority of immune response to MenACWY-TT co-administered with Tdap to MenACWY-TT given alone was demonstrated for all 4 meningococcal serogroups.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: However, despite high seropositivity (>90%) and vaccine response rates that were similar among groups, rSBA GMTs for each serogroup were lower in participants who received Tdap before MenACWY-TT.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Interestingly, when co-administered with MenACWY-DT, non-inferiority criteria based on booster response were met for all 3 pertussis antigens [44,45].

body_text.sentence: Moreover, a previous study showed that children aged 12–23 months receiving a dipththeria-tetanus-acellular pertussis-hepatitis B-inactivated polio-Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine (DTaP-HBV-IPV/Hib; Infanrix hexa, GSK) before MenACWY-TT had lower rSBA GMTs, but similar seroprotection rates, compared to the reverse schedule [33].
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: As the use of rSBA seropositivity (assessed as titers above a certain threshold [1:8]) rates as a serological surrogate of protection is still debatable, in particular for serogroups A, W and Y, rSBA GMT ratios were employed for defining the criteria to assess non-inferiority of immune responses to each meningococcal serogroup, similarly to previous studies [27–29].

body_text.sentence: At 1 month post-vaccination with Tdap, ≥98.2% of participants were seropositive for anti-PT, -FHA or -PRN (Table 1).

body_text.sentence: In America, Europe and Australia, MenB and MenC are the most common [4], with both MenY and MenW prevalence increasing lately in Europe and Latin America [3,5] while the emergence of MenW was also reported in Australia [6].

body_text.sentence: Post-vaccination GMCs in all groups were >53.6, ≥316.9 and ≥219.2 for PT, FHA and PRN, respectively.
body_text.title: Immunogenicity

body_text.sentence: Immunogenicity of Tdap co-administered with MenACWY-TT was non-inferior to its separate administration for diphtheria and tetanus.

body_text.sentence: With a target sample size of 600 participants, the global power to meet all primary objectives was ≥91.37%.
body_text.title: Statistical analyses

body_text.sentence: The antibody levels to pertussis antigens after Tdap administration in the current study were higher than those elicited by 3 doses of DTaP in infants [48], in a trial which demonstrated good efficacy of DTaP (88.7%) following household exposure, with protection against pertussis lasting until at least the time of the recommended booster dose [49].

body_text.sentence: Although a decreased immune response to Tdap in terms of FHA and PRN GMCs was observed, the clinical relevance of this observation is most likely limited and therefore the data support co-administration of Tdap and MenACWY-TT in adolescents.
body_text.title: Conclusion

body_text.sentence: Treatment allocation was performed at the investigators’ site using an internet-based randomization system, with a minimization algorithm accounting for center and age stratum (11–17 and 18–25 years).

body_text.sentence: Exploratory analyses comparing the Co-ad and Tdap_ACWY groups suggested that antibody GMCs were higher in the Tdap_ACWY group than in the Co-ad group for FHA and PRN.
body_text.title: Immunogenicity

body_text.sentence: It is reasonable to assume that co-administration of Tdap with MenACWY-TT in adolescents will be at least as efficacious as DTaP in preventing pertussis.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: The percentages of participants with anti-D concentrations ≥0.1 IU/ml and ≥1 IU/ml at 1 month post-Tdap administration were ≥99.1% and ≥88.9% (Table 1).

body_text.sentence: Serious AEs (SAEs) and new onset of chronic illnesses (e.g., asthma, autoimmune disorders, type 1 diabetes and allergies) were documented throughout the study.

body_text.sentence: The study was conducted in accordance with Good Clinical Practice guidelines and the Declaration of Helsinki.

body_text.sentence: Considering approximately 13% of unevaluable participants for immunogenicity, 690 participants were planned to be enrolled.
body_text.title: Statistical analyses

body_text.sentence: Fatigue was the most common general AE, reported by 32.5%, 27.2% and 28.0% of participants post-first vaccination visit in the Co-ad, ACWY_Tdap and Tdap_ACWY groups, and by 20.4% and 19.4% of participants post-second vaccination visit in the ACWY_Tdap and Tdap_ACWY groups (Fig. 4B).

body_text.sentence: Non-inferiority of MenACWY-TT co-administered with Tdap versus MenACWY-TT given alone was demonstrated if the lower limit (LL) of the 2-sided 95% confidence interval (CI) for the rSBA GMT ratio (Co-ad/ACWY_Tdap group) at Month 1 was ≥0.5 for each serogroup.
body_text.title: Statistical analyses

body_text.sentence: Non-inferiority of Tdap co-administered with MenACWY-TT versus Tdap given alone was demonstrated for D and T in terms of percentage of participants with antibody levels above 1 IU/ml (Fig. 2B).

body_text.sentence: Grade 3 and vaccine-related grade 3 unsolicited AEs were reported by ≤1.3% and ≤0.4% of participants following each dose.

body_text.sentence: This study was limited by the stringent non-inferiority criteria for the pertussis immune response.

body_text.sentence: The lower GMTs for PRN and FHA observed in groups where Tdap was administered either concurrently with or after MenACWY-TT vaccination may be the result of bystander interference.

metadata.title: Immunogenicity and safety of the quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine MenACWY-TT co-administered with a combined diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine versus their separate administration in adolescents and young adults: A phase III, randomized study
